Attribute.name: dc.description
Attribute.value: St George's Conservation Area was originally designated in May 1989, and covered an area of approximately 5.73 hectares. The conservation area was enlarged in 2003, and now extends to approximately 10.69 hectares.In July 2003, the Council approved a Character Statement as supplementary planning guidance to the City of Leicester Local Plan.The conservation area includes St George's Churchyard and parts of Rutland Street, Humberstone Gate and Wharf Street South.A Heritage Economic Regeneration...

Attribute.name: dc.description
Attribute.value: The St George's North and South Area Strategy Guidance was adopted by the City Council on 27 June 2005.To enable comprehensive approach to the whole of St George's, this Area Strategy Guidance is for the LRC intervention area New Community and the LCC Cultural Quarter.The purpose of the guidance is to: Illustrate clear planning and urban design guidance for St George's North and South. It provides a 'vision' for the area.Promote a mix of land use at an appropriate density to...

Attribute.name: dc.description
Attribute.value: Core Statement of General Policies 2.1. Leicester continues to need more houses, jobs and other facilities. Unlike many other cities it does not have a plentiful supply of new land for buildings within its border. Nor does it have a legacy of major industrial dereliction from which it can draw substantial amounts of brownfield land. At the same time it is a City very conscious of the need to safeguard and improve its environment and, where there is industrial dereliction, to generate new jobs...

Attribute.name: dc.description
Attribute.value: In July 2003, the City Council adopted a Character Statement for the St George's Conservation Area, as Supplementary Planning Guidance to the City of Leicester Local Plan. The council is in the process of reviewing the adopted Character Statement and the draft version can be downloaded below. More information regarding the consultation can be found here.You can view the Character Statements by clicking the links below. The text is in MS Word format; the maps are in PDF format.
